title: Chinese company donates railway machinery to Sri Lanka
description: The China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC) donated machinery and equipment worth 200,000 US dollars to Sri Lanka for the tsunami-hit country to repair its railway tracks. The machinery and equipment donated included rail drilling machine, rail cutting machine, hydraulic adjusting sleeper tool, hydraulic tamping machine, and hydraulic turnout tamping machine.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese company donates railway machinery to Sri Lanka

# Description
The China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC) donated machinery and equipment worth 200,000 US dollars to Sri Lanka for the tsunami-hit country to repair its railway tracks. The machinery and equipment donated included rail drilling machine, rail cutting machine, hydraulic adjusting sleeper tool, hydraulic tamping machine, and hydraulic turnout tamping machine.
justification: Project involves donation of railway repair equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Railway machinery donation for track repair, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China donates third batch of tsunami relief goods to Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami (Linked to #33226, #33234)
description: On 26 December 2004, a severe earthquake near the Indonesian island of Sumatra triggered an enormous tsunami in the Indian Ocean that hit many countries, including Sri Lanka. In response, the Chinese government sent three aid packages for tsunami relief to Sri Lanka. This project captures the third batch consisting of 770 sets of gasoline generators, food, and medicine which all arrived in Sri Lanka on 15 January 2005.   The other two aid packages are captured in project #33226 and #33234.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates third batch of tsunami relief goods to Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami (Linked to #33226, #33234)

# Description
On 26 December 2004, a severe earthquake near the Indonesian island of Sumatra triggered an enormous tsunami in the Indian Ocean that hit many countries, including Sri Lanka. In response, the Chinese government sent three aid packages for tsunami relief to Sri Lanka. This project captures the third batch consisting of 770 sets of gasoline generators, food, and medicine which all arrived in Sri Lanka on 15 January 2005.   The other two aid packages are captured in project #33226 and #33234.
justification: Project is focused on emergency relief and humanitarian aid, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Gasoline generators, food, and medicine for tsunami relief, humanitarian aid context

title: China sends 11-member expert team to help Sri Lanka with reconstruction efforts
description: On January 19, 2005, an 11-member Chinese expert team from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOC), Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Civil Affairs arrived in Sri Lanka to 1) evaluate local conditions in the wake of the killer tsunami, 2) help local governments in the country to resume the power supply and communications and 3) reconstruct the infrastructure facilities. The expert team, China built for international relief efforts, left China's capital Beijing for Sri Lanka on Jan 17 and left 10 days later on Jan 27.
staff_comments: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual projects are captured in the linked resource #41811.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China sends 11-member expert team to help Sri Lanka with reconstruction efforts

# Description
On January 19, 2005, an 11-member Chinese expert team from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOC), Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Civil Affairs arrived in Sri Lanka to 1) evaluate local conditions in the wake of the killer tsunami, 2) help local governments in the country to resume the power supply and communications and 3) reconstruct the infrastructure facilities. The expert team, China built for international relief efforts, left China's capital Beijing for Sri Lanka on Jan 17 and left 10 days later on Jan 27.
justification: Project focuses on disaster relief and infrastructure reconstruction without specific energy or environmental components
evidence: Expert team assisting with power supply restoration and infrastructure reconstruction following tsunami

title: China Eximbank provides $300 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase I of Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Linked to Project ID#33463 and #33452)
description: On August 30, 2005, China Eximbank signed a $300 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka for the Phase I of Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project. The PBC (captured via Project ID#33244) carries a 20 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, and an interest rate of 2%. It had disbursed $142,821,238.39 as of December 31, 2007 (Rs. 15,792,886,899) and $168,963,610.51 as of December 31, 2008 (Rs. 18,303,490,000). The borrower made repayments worth $19,978,236.69 in 2014 (Rs. 2,608,894,000). The PBC’s amount outstanding was $270,343,633.50 (Rs. 35,303,310,000) as of December 31, 2013, $210,000,000 as of December 31, 2016, and $100,000,000 as of June 30, 2022. On September 8, 2006, China Eximbank signed a $152,982,428 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) with the Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka for Phase I of the Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project. The BCL (captured via Project ID#33463) carries a 15 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, and a 6% interest rate. The BCL’s amount outstanding was $3,960,517.11 (Rs. 517,191,257) as of December 31, 2013, $130,035,063 as of December 31, 2016, and $45,894,728 as of June 30, 2022.   The Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka then used the proceeds from the BCL and PBC to on-lend to Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), which is a state-owned electricity company that controls all major functions of electricity generation, transmission, distribution and retailing in Sri Lanka. This project involved the installation of a 300MW coal power plant, a jetty for coal handling, and transmission lines from Norochcholai to Veyangoda and substation at Veyangoda. China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A project inauguration ceremony took place on May 11, 2006. Phase I construction began on July 23, 2007. The first 300-megawatt phase was completed and ceremonially commissioned by President Mahinda Rajapaksa on March 22, 2011.  However, there are indications that project has encountered debt repayment problems. In 2021, CEB disclosed that the Sri Lankan Treasury had ‘take[n] over [its] repayment obligation[s] due to non-availability of appropriate income based on the tariff approved by [Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka].’ Then, on April 12, 2022, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a ‘pre-emptive’ sovereign debt default, noting that it would suspend debt repayments to all external creditors other than multilateral institutions. Its decision to suspend external debt service reportedly affected all China Eximbank loans with amounts outstanding at the time of the announcement.
staff_comments: 1. For information on Phase II of the Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project, see Project ID#33452.2. The Chinese project title is 普特拉姆燃煤电站. 3. This Puttalam/Norochcholai power plant is sometimes referred to as the Lakvijaya power plant. 4. The Government of Sri Lanka loan key number is 2005045.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $300 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase I of Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project (Linked to Project ID#33463 and #33452)

# Description
On August 30, 2005, China Eximbank signed a $300 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka for the Phase I of Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project. The PBC (captured via Project ID#33244) carries a 20 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, and an interest rate of 2%. It had disbursed $142,821,238.39 as of December 31, 2007 (Rs. 15,792,886,899) and $168,963,610.51 as of December 31, 2008 (Rs. 18,303,490,000). The borrower made repayments worth $19,978,236.69 in 2014 (Rs. 2,608,894,000). The PBC’s amount outstanding was $270,343,633.50 (Rs. 35,303,310,000) as of December 31, 2013, $210,000,000 as of December 31, 2016, and $100,000,000 as of June 30, 2022. On September 8, 2006, China Eximbank signed a $152,982,428 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) with the Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka for Phase I of the Puttalam/Norochcholai Coal Power Project. The BCL (captured via Project ID#33463) carries a 15 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, and a 6% interest rate. The BCL’s amount outstanding was $3,960,517.11 (Rs. 517,191,257) as of December 31, 2013, $130,035,063 as of December 31, 2016, and $45,894,728 as of June 30, 2022.   The Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka then used the proceeds from the BCL and PBC to on-lend to Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), which is a state-owned electricity company that controls all major functions of electricity generation, transmission, distribution and retailing in Sri Lanka. This project involved the installation of a 300MW coal power plant, a jetty for coal handling, and transmission lines from Norochcholai to Veyangoda and substation at Veyangoda. China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A project inauguration ceremony took place on May 11, 2006. Phase I construction began on July 23, 2007. The first 300-megawatt phase was completed and ceremonially commissioned by President Mahinda Rajapaksa on March 22, 2011.  However, there are indications that project has encountered debt repayment problems. In 2021, CEB disclosed that the Sri Lankan Treasury had ‘take[n] over [its] repayment obligation[s] due to non-availability of appropriate income based on the tariff approved by [Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka].’ Then, on April 12, 2022, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a ‘pre-emptive’ sovereign debt default, noting that it would suspend debt repayments to all external creditors other than multilateral institutions. Its decision to suspend external debt service reportedly affected all China Eximbank loans with amounts outstanding at the time of the announcement.
justification: Primary purpose is coal power generation, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: 300MW coal power plant, coal handling jetty, and related infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides $18.2 million grant for post-tsunami reconstruction of Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishing harbors
description: On February 21, 2005, Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $18,207,786 grant agreement for the post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors in Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela (on the country’s western and southern coasts). Reconstruction efforts seem to begin around June 2005, but no specific date is found.  China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began in 2005, and the project was completed on December 28, 2007.
staff_comments: The Chinese Government reportedly contributed $63 million in total for tsunami relief projects. Most of the individual projects that the Chinese Government financed are captured in AidData’s dataset and linked to Project ID #41811.
combined_text:
# Sector
RECONSTRUCTION RELIEF AND REHABILITATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides $18.2 million grant for post-tsunami reconstruction of Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishing harbors

# Description
On February 21, 2005, Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $18,207,786 grant agreement for the post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors in Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela (on the country’s western and southern coasts). Reconstruction efforts seem to begin around June 2005, but no specific date is found.  China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began in 2005, and the project was completed on December 28, 2007.
justification: Project focuses on reconstruction of fishing harbors for post-tsunami relief, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors, no mention of energy or environmental components

title: China gives Sri Lanka 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD as part of its tsunami relief efforts
description: On June 29, 2005, China granted 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD to Sri Lanka as part of its tsunami relief efforts. The aid was administered by the World Food Programme (WFP). It is the first of two such shipments, worth a total of US$1 million, to support WFP food-for-work schemes to help Sri Lanka after the tsunami.
staff_comments: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual projects are captured (see projects linked with resource #41811).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China gives Sri Lanka 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD as part of its tsunami relief efforts

# Description
On June 29, 2005, China granted 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD to Sri Lanka as part of its tsunami relief efforts. The aid was administered by the World Food Programme (WFP). It is the first of two such shipments, worth a total of US$1 million, to support WFP food-for-work schemes to help Sri Lanka after the tsunami.
justification: Project is humanitarian aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Food aid for tsunami relief, administered through WFP food-for-work schemes

title: Chinese Government provides USD 106,550 grant to WHO for health coordination in Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami
description: According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service, on 4 April 2005, the Chinese Government committed to donating $106,550 USD to the World Health Organization (WHO) for "enhancing capacity to respond to health threats at regional level and supporting health coordination" in Sri Lanka.   This project falls under a broader initiative (UN project name is TSU-REG-05/H01- REGION) "to support national health authorities to protect the health of survivors and vulnerable people affected by the disaster, to provide early warning of emergency health threats and to enable the timely organisation of any response, to work with the Ministries of Health and with partners in the coordination of the health sector response".
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides USD 106,550 grant to WHO for health coordination in Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami

# Description
According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service, on 4 April 2005, the Chinese Government committed to donating $106,550 USD to the World Health Organization (WHO) for "enhancing capacity to respond to health threats at regional level and supporting health coordination" in Sri Lanka.   This project falls under a broader initiative (UN project name is TSU-REG-05/H01- REGION) "to support national health authorities to protect the health of survivors and vulnerable people affected by the disaster, to provide early warning of emergency health threats and to enable the timely organisation of any response, to work with the Ministries of Health and with partners in the coordination of the health sector response".
justification: Project focuses on health coordination and emergency response without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Grant for health coordination following natural disaster, focus on emergency response and health sector coordination

title: China donates $200,000 USD to UNFPA for reproductive health services in Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami
description: On 26 December 2004, a severe earthquake near the Indonesian island of Sumatra triggered an enormous tsunami in the Indian Ocean that hit many countries, including Sri Lanka. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service (flow ID #26886), on 11 January 2005, the Chinese government committed to donating $200,000 USD to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) for "restoration of reproductive health services" in Sri Lanka (UN project name is TSU-SRL-05/H03-SRI LANKA). The funds began flowing on 18 February 2005.   The purpose of this project was "to re-establish reproductive health services through immediate implementation of the Minimum Initial Service Package (MISP); to provide for safe deliveries and emergency obstetric care; to reduce STI and HIV transmission; and to prevent and manage the consequences of sexual violence".
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates $200,000 USD to UNFPA for reproductive health services in Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami

# Description
On 26 December 2004, a severe earthquake near the Indonesian island of Sumatra triggered an enormous tsunami in the Indian Ocean that hit many countries, including Sri Lanka. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service (flow ID #26886), on 11 January 2005, the Chinese government committed to donating $200,000 USD to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) for "restoration of reproductive health services" in Sri Lanka (UN project name is TSU-SRL-05/H03-SRI LANKA). The funds began flowing on 18 February 2005.   The purpose of this project was "to re-establish reproductive health services through immediate implementation of the Minimum Initial Service Package (MISP); to provide for safe deliveries and emergency obstetric care; to reduce STI and HIV transmission; and to prevent and manage the consequences of sexual violence".
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and reproductive health services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation for restoration of reproductive health services, emergency obstetric care, and STI/HIV prevention

title: China provided $4.33 million debt forgiveness for government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations
description: In April 2005, after the 2004 tsunami, the Chinese Government cancelled $4.33 million of the Government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations (the transaction amount shown in the 2005 annual report of Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance and Planning). This action represented a partial rather than total write-off of the Government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese name of the agreement is '中华人民共和国政府和斯里兰卡民主社会主义共和国政府关于免除斯里兰卡政府部分债务议定.'2. The loans forgiven through this action were almost certainly interest-free loans committed through previous ETCAs. As such, the loans likely had maturity lengths of 20 years and since they had reached maturity no later than 2005, they were almost certainly contracted prior to 2000. Therefore, AidData has not assigned this record to the umbrella category (as there is little risk of double counting the monetary value of the debts that were forgiven).'
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China provided $4.33 million debt forgiveness for government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
In April 2005, after the 2004 tsunami, the Chinese Government cancelled $4.33 million of the Government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations (the transaction amount shown in the 2005 annual report of Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance and Planning). This action represented a partial rather than total write-off of the Government of Sri Lanka’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government.
justification: Debt forgiveness is a financial transaction without direct environmental impact or energy transition implications
evidence: Debt forgiveness action, no specific project or environmental impact mentioned
